Jenny Wilkinson/Correspondent By Larry Truong Correspondent Published: Sunday, August 7, 2011 at 6:01 a.m. Last Modified: Friday, August 5, 2011 at 5:18 p.m. In a town full of college students, high schoolers often have a hard time competing for summer jobs with older and more qualified applicants. But what they lack in age and experience, high schoolers can make up for in preparation, dedication and enthusiasm. Rashad Harding, 18, who graduated from P.K. Yonge Developmental Research School in May, not only has a summer job, he has three. He is working at two apparel stores at the Oaks Mall—Abercrombie&Fitch and American Eagle Outfitters—and also at Vector Marketing as a kitchen cutlery salesperson. He has worked for Abercrombie&Fitch, which was his first job, since last summer, and started at American Eagle and Vector this summer. "It was actually really easy because I always come really prepared," Harding said about securing his summer jobs. "A lot of people don't expect an 18-year-old to have a resume and cover letter." Harding said he also did research on each of the companies before he went in for the interview to find out more about each company's expectations. He said that doing this type of preparation, along with dressing the part for each job during the interview, helped him get hired. "You have to apply early, not whenever you feel like it," he said. Nationally, the teen unemployment rate stands at 24.5 percent, almost three times the national unemployment rate, according to the Employment Policies Institute, a nonprofit research organization dedicated to studying public policy issues surrounding employment growth. Teens classified as "unemployed" are those who are actively seeking a job but can't get one. Florida's unemployment rate for 16- to 19-year-olds is 29.4 percent, the ninth highest in the nation. The state with the highest teenage unemployment rate is California at 34.6 percent. Despite the discouraging numbers, teenage workers typically turn to the retail sector, including fast-food restaurants and retail clothing stores, to seek work. Another attractive—albeit competitive—option for teenagers is working at the neighborhood pool. Jeff Moffitt, aquatics supervisor of Gainesville's three community pools, said there are currently five high school students working as lifeguards or pool attendants this summer. He said that although he does hire teenagers, they have to have CPR and lifeguard certifications and keep those certifications up-to-date. Fast-food restaurant Chick-fil-A hires employees as young as 16. Steve Carroll, owner of the Chick-fil-A at the Oaks Mall for 33 years, said that nearly 40 percent of his current employees are teenagers. He said that when he's looking to hire any employee, the first impression he or she makes is the most important. "Are they pleasant? Can they smile? Can they communicate?" said Carroll about what he looks for during the interview. "But first of all, they need to be themselves. If they don't have those traits, it'll wear off real quick." Allyson Livingston, 17, started working at Carroll's store at the start of summer. A rising senior at Cornerstone Christian Academy, Livingston said she was well prepared for her job interview after getting plenty of practice in her high school speech and debate class. "My teacher knew we were at the age to get jobs, so we went over interviewing techniques," she said. "We practiced not being shy and being ourselves." Livingston advises other high school students applying for jobs to relax. "Don't sweat it," she said. "They're not there to attack you. They just want to ask you questions to get to know you."
